intro: Loranthus betchei var. tomentellus, commonly known as the woolly mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees, primarily in the Mediterranean region. It has a distinctive appearance with its dense, woolly foliage that gives it its common name. The plant produces small, white or greenish flowers that are often clustered together. Its berries are typically red or orange and contain seeds that are dispersed by birds. This species plays an important ecological role by providing food for wildlife and contributing to the biodiversity of its habitat.
